Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students set up a system of two blocks and an inclined plane, as shown in the figure. Block <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></math> of mass <math alttext="M sub 1 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is on a surface that is inclined at an angle <math alttext="theta " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to the horizontal. The friction between block <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></math> and the surface is negligible. A string is attached to block <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></math>, extends over an ideal pulley, and is then attached to block <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></math> of mass <math alttext="M sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> .

(a) In an initial setup, <math alttext="M sub 1 equals 3 M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="M sub 2 equals M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> . Calculate the value of <math alttext="theta " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that would allow the system to remain in equilibrium.

The original inclined plane is now replaced with one that has a rough surface. The coefficients of static and kinetic friction between block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></math> and the surface are <math alttext="mu sub s " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , respectively. Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></math> is again chosen so that <math alttext="M sub 1 equals M " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> .
(b) Derive an expression for the maximum value of <math alttext="M sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that would allow this system to remain in equilibrium. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="mu sub s " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , and physical constants, as appropriate.

Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></math> of mass <math alttext="M sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is now chosen such that block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></math> will accelerate up the inclined plane.
(c)
i. Derive an expression for the magnitude of the acceleration of block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="M sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="mu sub k " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="theta " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

ii. Derive an expression for the tension in the string. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="M sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, <math alttext="M sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(d) On the axes below, sketch the speed <math alttext="v " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> moved by block 1 up the inclined plane as functions of time.

(e) During the experiments, students collect data that shows the acceleration of the blocks actually increases while the blocks are in motion.

i. On this axis below, sketch the speed <math alttext="v " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of block <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></math> as a function of <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> .
ii. Explain why the experiment may have produced an increasing acceleration instead of the predicted constant acceleration.
